subject: RE: [junit] printing my own debug messages
msgSnippet: log4j *is* heavyweight in that it is scaleable to satisfy all your enterprise logging needs - tracking alerts, system errors, etc in patterns that you can
messageBody:
log4j *is* heavyweight in that it is scaleable to satisfy all your
enterprise logging needs - tracking alerts, system errors, etc in patterns
that you can define yourself. However if all you want to do is spew out
debug messages to a text file that's cool, log4j can handle it without very
much configuring. actually logging a message requires no more code than
system.out.println().

the good thing about it is that log4j recognises DEBUG as a logging level so
that you can leave your debug messages in your live code and just supress
the outputting of the message. this solves the problem of accidentally
introducing bugs when you clean out your system.out.println() calls prior to
going live. it also means those messages can be re-used the next time you
work on that code.

I'm not saying loh4j is perfect, but it is a lot better than re-inventing
the wheel.

rgds, APC


-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: 03 July 2001 14:34
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] printing my own debug messages


I looked at that some time ago for some simple logging needs we had, and it
seemed really heavyweight. Do you disagree? Do you think it can be scaled
down pretty easily?

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Andrew Clarke [mailto:andrew.clarke@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, July 03, 2001 9:07 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] printing my own debug messages
>
>
> Why not use another great piece of freeware, log4j?
> This can be downloaded
> from the Apache site.
>
> rgds, APC
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: steinbeck@... [mailto:steinbeck@...]
> Sent: 03 July 2001 14:01
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] printing my own debug messages
>
>
> Hi there,
>
> I've check all the available documentation on whether there is a
> possibility to print my own debug output messages from a
> test case in
> a controlled way - ideally I would like to get them in a
> "results.txt" like can be produced by the junit task in
> ant. It seems
> that this is not the way that I'm supposed to go, since
> there seems to
> be no option for that.
>
> Nevertheless, it would be nice to use the test case for debugging
> (until it works).
> It there an option for that?
>
> Cheers,
>
> Chris
>
